questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman comes to the physician for a screening Pap smear. She has no history of serious illness. Her last Pap smear was 10 years ago and showed no abnormalities. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks 3 bottles of wine per week. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her paternal grandmother had ovarian cancer and her maternal aunt had breast cancer. Pelvic examination shows multiple red, fleshy polypoid masses on the anterior vaginal wall. A biopsy is obtained and histology shows large cells with abundant clear cytoplasm. Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for this diagnosis?

choices.text: Family history of breast and ovarian cancer

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alcohol consumption is associated with an increased risk of developing numerous cancers, including breast cancer, esophageal squamous cell cancer, and hepatic cancer. However, there is no evidence that alcohol consumption is a risk factor for vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Cigarette smoking is a known risk factor for vaginal squamous cell cancer, which is the most common subtype of vaginal cancer. However, biopsy confirmed that this patient has vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma, which is not associated with exposure to cigarette smoke.

C) INCORRECT:

A family history of breast cancer and/or ovarian cancer is not associated with an increased risk of vaginal cancer. However, such a history may be associated with a BRCA mutation that increases the risk for breast cancer, ovarian cancer, and colorectal cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is the main causative factor for vaginal squamous cell cancer. HPV is also considered a risk factor for adenocarcinoma. Given this patient's history of multiple sexual partners and inconsistent use of condoms, she is likely to have an HPV infection. However, biopsy confirmed that this patient has vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma, which is a rare subtype of adenocarcinoma that is primarily associated with another risk factor.

E) CORRECT:

Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was introduced in the 1940s as it was believed to prevent miscarriage in pregnant women. In 1971, DES was discontinued because studies found that it is a potent transplacental carcinogen. It significantly increases the lifetime risk of vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma, a rare form of vaginal cancer, in daughters of the women who received DES. Therefore, women with a history of intrauterine DES exposure should be monitored closely.

DES also has a carcinogenic effect on the mothers who received DES during their pregnancy and has been associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.
questions.hint: Large cells with abundant clear cytoplasm are consistent with clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina.

questions.text: A 57-year-old postmenopausal woman comes to the physician because of intermittent, bloody postcoital vaginal discharge for the past month. She does not have pain with intercourse. Eleven years ago, she had a low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion on a routine Pap smear and testing for high-risk HPV strains was positive. Colposcopy showed cervical intraepithelial neoplasia 1. She has not returned for follow-up Pap smears since then. She is sexually active with her husband only, and they do not use condoms. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes per day for the past 25 years and does not drink alcohol. On speculum examination, a 1.4 cm, erythematous exophytic mass with ulceration is noted on the posterior wall of the upper third of the vagina. Which of the following is the most probable histopathology of this mass?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vaginal carcinoma (∼ 75% of cases). Most cases are caused by infection with HPV type 16 or 18. Other symptoms of a vaginal carcinoma include vaginal ulceration and a malodorous discharge. The next best step in the management of this patient is a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis, followed by cystourethroscopy, rectosigmoidoscopy, and pelvic imaging to assess the extent of growth and lymph node spread. In the case of carcinomas that are limited to the vaginal wall (stage I), the treatment is primarily surgical. For more advanced cancer, radiotherapy is the primary treatment.
Image Description:

Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia is the preliminary stage of an invasive vaginal carcinoma. Histological classification (based on WHO) occurs in LSIL (VAIN 1) and HSIL (VAIN 2&3).

B) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, a basal cell carcinoma can develop on the vulva, but it would not occur in the vagina.

C) INCORRECT:

Vaginal melanomas are seen in women 50–70 years of age and may manifest with postcoital bleeding. However, this tumor is extremely rare and typically occurs in the lower third of the vagina.

D) INCORRECT:

Sarcoma botryoides is an extremely rare form of vaginal carcinoma that occurs in girls < 8 years of age. The most common location is the anterior vaginal wall, and a polypoid mass that protrudes outside the vagina would be evident. A different diagnosis should be considered in this post-menopausal woman with an ulceroproliferative lesion on the posterior vaginal wall.

E) INCORRECT:

Vaginal adenocarcinomas can develop in patients older than 50 years of age and may manifest with postcoital bleeding, but they only account for 15% of all vaginal carcinomas. Vaginal adenocarcinomas are the primary vaginal cancer in women younger than 20 years of age and the most likely histology in patients with a history of intrauterine exposure to diethylstilbestrol.
questions.hint: The patient's lesion is likely secondary to the human papillomavirus (HPV), which is the most common cause of primary vaginal cancer.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal spotting and urinary urgency for the past 4 days. She has had no fever, abdominal pain, or diarrhea. Menopause occurred at 52 years of age. Her last Pap smear 1 year ago was normal. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include atorvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, and aspirin. She is sexually active with her husband. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 155/65 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a 4 x 3 cm nontender, firm, immobile erythematous mass on the right inner vaginal wall. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vulvectomy may be appropriate for patients with confirmed dysplasia or malignancy of the vulva. Although this patient has a concerning lesion, malignancy has not been confirmed. Moreover, her mass is located within the vaginal canal without clear extension into the vulva; vulvectomy may not be required.

B) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound can be used to evaluate the endometrium for postmenopausal women with abnormal bleeding from the uterus. This patient's vaginal bleeding most likely arises from the mass on her vaginal wall, which warrants evaluation before examining other causes of postmenopausal bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Pap smear and HPV co-testing should be performed every 5 years for women 30 to 65 years old (Pap smear alone every 3 years is also considered, by the ACOG, as an acceptable screening strategy in this age group). This patient already had a normal Pap smear 1 year ago. She has a grossly visible vaginal lesion that should be examined first.

D) CORRECT:

Vaginal cancer most commonly manifests as postmenopausal bleeding, and a pelvic exam will usually show a mass (or plaque) on the vaginal wall. Some patients can have symptoms related to the local extension of the disease, such as urinary frequency. Definitive diagnosis requires a biopsy of the suspicious lesion and histological confirmation. The majority of vaginal cancers are carcinomas, related to high-risk HPV. If a biopsy is positive, this patient will require clinical staging with cystoscopy, proctoscopy, and chest and skeletal radiography. Treatment requires surgical excision with or without radiation and chemotherapy, depending on the stage of cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Vaginal (and cervical) colposcopy is appropriate in patients with abnormal cytology results without a clearly visible lesion during a pelvic exam; colposcopy can magnify the tissue to allow for better detection of lesions that should be sampled. Because this patient's lesion is clearly visible, a vaginal colposcopy is not necessary at this time. Some clinicians may use vaginal colposcopy to visualize the remainder of the vagina when a gross lesion is detected on the vaginal wall. However, vaginal colposcopy would not take precedent over another procedure to diagnose this patient's gross lesion first.

F) INCORRECT:

Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) is used to remove high-grade intraepithelial lesions of the cervix. However, this patient's concerning lesion is located on the vaginal wall, not the cervix. Furthermore, LEEP is only performed after there is confirmation of dysplasia.

G) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage would be appropriate for a vaginal abscess or Bartholin gland abscess, both of which can manifest as an erythematous mass on the vaginal wall, as seen in this patient. However, abscesses are usually painful and may have purulent discharge. This patient's painless mass with bleeding suggests another diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Urine gonorrhea and chlamydia testing are indicated in cervicitis, which can manifest as vaginal spotting and urinary urgency (due to concomitant urethral infection). In cervicitis, the cervix would have purulent discharge and friability. This patient's normal-appearing cervix and grossly visible vaginal lesion suggest another diagnosis.
Image Description:

Colposcopy view of the ectocervix

The ectocervix is erythematous and there is purulent discharge from the external os.
questions.hint: Until proven otherwise, the cause of postmenopausal vaginal bleeding should be considered malignant.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of intermittent burning sensation in the genital region. During this time, she has occasionally been experiencing pain during sexual intercourse. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. The patient has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. She is sexually active with multiple partners. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a 3-cm, raised, erythematous mass with whitish discoloration on the right labia majora. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. Punch biopsy of the lesion shows dysplastic squamous cells with invasion of the basement membrane. Colposcopy and cervical cytology show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-potency steroids are indicated in the treatment of lichen sclerosus, which can manifest with an erythematous, whitish lesion in the labia majora. However, a punch biopsy would show epidermal atrophy with hyperkeratosis rather than dysplastic squamous cells. Moreover, lichen sclerosus' dominant symptom is severe pruritus.

B) INCORRECT:

Curettage is a treatment option for anogenital warts, which can manifest with exophytic, vulvar lesions. Although a punch biopsy of a genital wart would also show dysplastic cells, invasion of the basement membrane would not be expected. Invasion of the basement membrane is consistent with invasive vulvar cancer, for which curettage is not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Radical vulvectomy is usually the first-line treatment for patients with invasive vulvar cancer. Inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy may also be performed to assess lymph node involvement. In patients with extensive or unresectable disease (e.g., larger tumor size, invasion of adjacent structures), a combination of chemotherapy and radiation is generally preferred before surgery.

Patients with vulvar cancer typically present with a unifocal, erythematous, vulvar lesion that can be associated with local pruritus, a burning sensation, bleeding, and/or pain. Squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva is often associated with persistent human papillomavirus infection and smoking. Another risk factor for developing vulvar cancer is chronic inflammation, e.g., due to precancerous lesions like lichen sclerosus. Patients with lichen sclerosus should undergo punch biopsy to exclude squamous cell carcinoma.
Image Description:

Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) is the preliminary stage of an invasive vulvar carcinoma. Histological classification is based on WHO (VIN 1–3) or ISSVD (LSIL/HSIL).

D) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy is a treatment option for anogenital warts, which can manifest with exophytic vulvar lesions. Although a punch biopsy of a genital wart would also show dysplastic cells, invasion of the basement membrane would not be expected. Invasion of the basement membrane is consistent with invasive vulvar cancer, for which cryotherapy is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical chemotherapy can be used for the treatment of vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN). This patient's punch biopsy shows invasion of the basement membrane, which is not consistent with VIN but with invasive vulvar cancer, for which topical chemotherapy is not an appropriate treatment.
questions.hint: This patient's findings are consistent with squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman reports vaginal spotting and urinary urgency for the past 4 days. She has had no fever, abdominal pain, or diarrhea. Menopause occurred at 52 years of age. Her last Pap smear 1 year ago was normal. She is sexually active with her husband. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 155/65 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a 4 x 3 cm nontender, firm, immobile erythematous mass on the right inner vaginal wall. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Transvaginal ultrasound can be used to evaluate the endometrium for postmenopausal women with abnormal bleeding from the uterus. This patient's vaginal bleeding most likely arises from the mass on her vaginal wall, which warrants evaluation before examining other causes of postmenopausal bleeding.

However, abscesses are usually painful and may have purulent discharge. This patient's painless mass with bleeding suggests another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents with a six-month history of a persistent lesion on the lateral vulva accompanied by pruritus. She has no significant medical history. Physical examination reveals a 2-cm area of irregular thickening. Biopsy confirms vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (carcinoma in situ). She is concerned about preserving normal anatomy and function (see report).
Biopsy: Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (carcinoma in situ)
Which management approach is most appropriate to ensure complete removal of the lesion while minimizing unnecessary tissue resection?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laser ablation is minimally invasive but does not provide a specimen for histopathological evaluation, precluding margin assessment. This limitation is significant in carcinoma in situ, where confirming complete lesion removal and excluding microinvasive disease is essential.

B) CORRECT:

Local superficial excision is the preferred management for vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) or carcinoma in situ. This approach involves removing the dysplastic lesion with a margin of normal tissue, allowing for histopathological assessment of surgical margins to confirm complete excision. This method ensures oncologic control while preserving vulvar anatomy and function, which is crucial for a localized 2-cm lesion. It balances the need for complete lesion removal with the patient's concern for maintaining normal anatomy.

Key learning point: Local superficial excision is the preferred management for vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia with carcinoma in situ to ensure complete removal of the lesion while preserving normal tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical imiquimod is an immunomodulatory treatment that can clear dysplastic cells but does not allow for histopathological margin verification. In a confirmed carcinoma in situ, ensuring complete lesion removal with precise margin control is critical, which imiquimod cannot guarantee.

D) INCORRECT:

Simple vulvectomy involves extensive tissue removal, which is unnecessary for a localized 2-cm lesion. It risks complications and functional impairments, making it unsuitable for a patient prioritizing preservation of vulvar anatomy and function.

questions.text: You are seeing a 55-year-old postmenopausal woman in your clinic for a screening Pap smear. She has no history of serious illness. Her last Pap smear was 10 years ago and was normal. She has a 20-year history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks 3 bottles of wine per week. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her paternal grandmother had ovarian cancer and her maternal aunt had breast cancer. On pelvic examination, there are multiple red, fleshy polypoid masses on the anterior vaginal wall. A biopsy shows large cells with abundant clear cytoplasm. Which one of the following is the most significant risk factor for this diagnosis?

choices.text: Family history of breast and ovarian cancer.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cigarette smoking is a known risk factor for vaginal squamous cell cancer, which is the most common subtype of vaginal cancer. However, biopsy confirmed that this patient has vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma, which is not associated with exposure to cigarette smoke.

B) CORRECT:

Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was introduced in the 1940s as it was believed to prevent miscarriage in pregnant women. In 1971, DES was discontinued because studies found that it is a potent transplacental carcinogen. It significantly increases the lifetime risk of vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma, a rare form of vaginal cancer, in daughters of the women who received DES. Therefore, women with a history of intrauterine DES exposure should be monitored closely.

DES also has a carcinogenic effect on the mothers who received DES during their pregnancy and has been associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.

Key learning point: In utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) is the most significant risk factor for developing vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma later in life.

C) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is the main causative factor for vaginal squamous cell cancer. HPV is also considered a risk factor for adenocarcinoma. Given this patient's history of multiple sexual partners and inconsistent use of condoms, she is likely to have an HPV infection. However, biopsy confirmed that this patient has vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma, which is a rare subtype of adenocarcinoma that is primarily associated with another risk factor.

D) INCORRECT:

Alcohol consumption is associated with an increased risk of developing numerous cancers, including breast cancer, esophageal squamous cell cancer, and hepatic cancer. However, there is no evidence that alcohol consumption is a risk factor for vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

A family history of breast cancer and/or ovarian cancer is not associated with an increased risk of vaginal cancer. However, such a history may be associated with a BRCA mutation that increases the risk for breast cancer, ovarian cancer, and colorectal cancer.
questions.hint: Large cells with abundant clear cytoplasm are consistent with clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman has had progressive vulvar pruritus and a raised lesion with discrete regular borders on her labia majora for three months. Which histologic subtype is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malignant melanomas typically occur in sun-exposed areas and are a rare cause of vulvar cancer. Malignant melanoma is considered for pigmented vulvar lesions, presenting with irregular borders and heterogeneous pigmentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Paget disease of the vulva is an adenocarcinoma that presents as an erythematous, eczematous lesion with ill-defined borders (often mimicking dermatitis), not as a discrete raised mass. The described nodular lesion suggests a different epithelial malignancy that is a much more common cause of vulvar cancer.

C) CORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common vulvar cancer, accounting for about 80–90% of cases. It often presents with chronic vulvar pruritus and a raised or ulcerative lesion on the labia majora. The pathogenesis in older women may involve chronic inflammatory conditions like lichen sclerosis, which predispose the vulvar epithelium to malignant transformation. Other risk factors include high-risk HPV infection, smoking, and immunosuppression. Histologically, SCC is characterized by keratinizing malignant cells with intercellular bridges and varying degrees of atypia.

Key learning point: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vulvar neoplasm.

D) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) typically arises in sun-exposed areas and is a rare cause of vulvar cancer. BCC usually presents as a pearly lesion with telangiectasia.
